Problem:
Consider a continuous-time Markov chain with state transition rates described by the matrix \\(Q\\). We examine the transformation effect of the matrix exponential \\(P(t) = e^{Qt}\\) on the probability distribution vector \\(\\pi(0)\\) over time t.

If the transformation \\(P(t)\\) is applied to a probability distribution vector \\(\\pi(0)\\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under its intrinsic state transitions described by \\(Q\\) without further intervention, will the probability distribution \\(\\pi(T)\\) at t = T be the same as if \\(\\pi(0)\\) was directly evolved to t = T under the matrix \\(Q\\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\(P(t) = e^{Qt}\\) exactly describes the evolution of the probability distribution over time under the state transitions defined by \\(Q\\). Therefore, the resulting state \\(\\pi(T)\\) is the same as it would be by directly applying \\(Q\\) to \\(\\pi(0)\\) over time T.

causal_map_integration: The state transition rate matrix Q determines both the matrix exponential P(t) and the direct evolution of the probability distribution π(T). P(t) transforms π(0) over time t, and Q directly evolves π(0) to π(T) over the same period.
